fields.Title of Contribution: <span style="font-size:11pt;">Building a practice ready and resilient nursing workforce. </span>
fields.Description/Abstract: Nurse leaders depend upon resiliency skills to support their practice. It is important to provide<br>opportunities for nursing students to learn, practice, and observe these skills, which are needed<br>to navigate challenging work environments. This article describes the impact of a resiliency curricular<br>component in a grant-funded BSN elective course, Concepts of Primary Care. Program<br>evaluation was performed using a pre/posttest format and 2 surveys, the Brief Resilience Scale<br>(BRS) and the Brief Resilience Coping Scale (BRCS). Three open-ended questions were administered<br>upon completion of the elective course. A concurrent nested design was utilized with<br>a thematic analysis undertaken to analyze qualitative data. Analysis of quantitative data was performed<br>using descriptive statistics. Undergraduate BSN students showed an overall increase in<br>resiliency (BRS: P = .112; BCRS: P = .064), and responses to open-ended questions supported<br>the ability to apply and analyze most of the resiliency skills presented during the didactic portion<br>of the elective course. This course promoted the development and refinement of undergraduate<br>BSN student resilience skills. Integration of resilience content in the primary care course also<br>supported student professional development. The addition of resiliency concepts and skills into<br>undergraduate nursing curricula is recommended to enhance the ability of novice nurses to ad[<br>AQ1] dress work-related challenges and promote career satisfaction for the future
